text: Hi ,contact us form is not submitting. please provide solution.

Hi Community,
I know this is is planning it seems but has anyone found an easier workaround?
Created custom modules that are in the footer of a blog post. I  need to change the languages so each footer matches its respective language. Is there another way without having to recreate each custom module?

I would contact HubSpot support. This slack is for the community of HubSpot developers. While HS employees do post from time to time, the slack is really intended for devs to help eachother.

Your specific issue seems like a javascript issue and either you have some javascript conflicting or HubSpot’s js is throwing an error.
I’ve done it where I just inserted a template partial based on the URL, as the site I was working on used URLs to separate the different language versions
Thanks for your input Jon. How can I test if that would work for me versus having to rebuild a bunch of modules?
well in your case instead of using the partials you could just use the custom modules, or even include the HubL logic inside your 1 existing custom module. all depends how you want to organize it

Right now for 5 different languages they all share the same custom modules and are all in English. What exactly and where would I apply a change that would allow for when edits are made to affect only that blog specifically?
well if you want it to be a manual thing then I would either use a topic for the language and use HubL to check if the post has that topic. If it does show the relevant version of the module.
hmm. Then end goal is for the footer to be in a different language for each blog without having to recreate modules. Is there a way you aware of that this can be done?
that’s exactly what I’m telling you

you detect which language topic is on a post, and default to whatever default language you want if no language topic is specified.

Then you display the footer with appropriate text and whatnot based on that language
you also get the side benefit that since you’re using topics, you also get listing pages for each language for free.
ohhhhhh
interesting

in the past though my clients wanted separate blogs for each language/region - the reason being if you go the approach of putting all of the languages in the same blog you’re going to get a mix of languages on your listing page. You can hide posts of different languages, but that can make pagination feel funky because you won’t always have a consistent number of posts.
well actually
on that listing page bit. it’s actually way easier
than I’m thinking
I’d simply offer a language picker - and choosing any of the languages takes you to the topic page. voila done. almost no work for you, and no pagination problem

Yeah I see what you're saying. In this case they already have different blogs in HubSpot so can't really use a language picker option.Have to somehow find a way to edit the footers of each with the right language.....

Wait, you’re saying they’re already different blogs? then what’s the issue? just edit the footers. If they’re using the same template, clone the template. edit the footer.

If you want to use the same code you could use a custom module, and make it so the text seen on screen is just fields in the module, lock the module so it can’t be edited on the post level, then for each of the cloned templates for the languages all you do is edit the default values for the fields of that module at the template level. voila no multiple code bases
does anyone know how to get the file url using the file field in HubSpot Design Manager?
{{ file_link.src }} doesn’t seem to do it
nvm
isnt it just the {{ module.file_field }}
yeah
hah
thanks
:slightly_smiling_face:
Do you have any thoughts on how to do a conditional statement based on file type?
if file = pdf
`string_containing`
<https://designers.HubSpot.com/docs/hubl/operators-and-expression-tests>

Not sure if it's a bug or not, but it looks like if you attach a stylesheet to a module directly and then add that module to a template that has the same CSS attached to it, that the CSS file is being loaded twice, regardless of how many times the module is added to the page. Is this the way it should be functioning?
Ideally no. This is something i honestly wanted to test for a possible strategy for <#CCQSQ2C6L|crankshaft> would be awesome if HS employees can take a look
